title: london reports coronavirus cases lockdown
story: The capital has been one of the hardest hit regions in the UK since its first reported case in February.On Monday no new cases of the killer bug were recorded in London and the East of England, according to data published yesterday by Public Health England.PHE Health chiefs have cautioned not to look too much into this figure as it could be an anomaly.A Department of Health spokesperson stressed this doesnt mean the epidemic is tailing off.On Sunday, PHE data shows  mores cases of Covid- were recorded in London - and the same figure on Saturday.Figures from Thursday and Friday show  and  more coronavirus cases were recorded in the capital.The latest figure could be attributed to a glitch similar to when the Covid- patient notication system stopped working temporarily on May .In London, a total of , people have died in hospital after testing positive for coronavirus, according to the PHE figures published for Tuesday.Data from the Office of National Statistics shows that , deaths related to coronavirus were recorded in London up to May .The declining number of cases and deaths is one of the five tests the UK needs to pass before lockdown is lted.Another one of the tests is to see the infection or R rate drop to below one.Lockdown rules began to ease last week, with sunbathing and unlimited exercise allowed - as long as Brits observe social distancing.Brits have also been toldthey can go back to work then they should, sparking commuting chaos in the capital as transport in London has been running on a reduced timetable.London Mayor Sadiq Khan has faced criticism after announcing plans to increase the charges for vehicles driving in central London and hike Underground fares.Pupils at some schools willin June, while pubs, cafes and restaurants could open to sell pints and food from market-style outdoor stalls in just weeks.The Prime Ministers spokesperson also hinted that some elements of the lockdown could be eased at dferent rates in dferent parts of the country.Boris Johnson’s spokesperson said the Recovery Strategy document released last Monday made it clear that the authorities would be responsive to new data on local infection rates when looking to ease lockdown.He said: It could lead to some of the measures being eased at dferent rates in dferent parts of the country and at the same time it could lead to some measures being re-imposed in some parts of the country but not in others.Last week, experts estimated the reproduction number has gone up from between . and . to between . and .But the governments top scientists cautioned that the small increase in the R value isnt thought to be linked due to a lag of about two to three weeks in data.Instead, they believe that as the total number of cases in the community is falling, the number in care homes and hospitals is accounting for a greater proportion of the total.Earlier this month, the North West over took London as Britain’s coronavirus epicentre with more hospital cases than the capital.Cases across the country have been steadily dropping after , new coronavirus cases were diagnosed yesterday - down from , the day before.The number of deaths has steadily been falling as well - despite yesterday being the highest rise in a week, with deaths jumping by .Mr Johnson hopes a slow phased unlocking of Britain will allow the country to slip back into some sort of new normal.The Government still needs to fulfill the five requirements needed to end lockdown.The five tests are: the ensure the NHS has the capacity to provide care, there is a sustained and consistent fall in daily deaths, the R rate drops to manageable levels, over coming operational challenges with PPE and testing and being confident in easing lockdown.The Sun Online contacted Public Health England for a comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus press briefing wednesday may 20 oliver dowden
story: The coronavirus briefings are held on a daily basis to provide an update to the nation with regards to how the government are tackling the Covid- crisis and what the public should do to protect themselves..Mr Dowden hosted the coronavirus press briefing alongside National Medical Director for England in the NHS, Stephen Powis.In his opening address, the Culture Secretary revealed that the number of deaths rose by , taking the total up to , in the UK.He reiterated that the Queens Birthday Honours List would be held off until the autumn to allow to recognise those bravely battling the coronavirus - including Captain Tom Moore who will receive a knighthood.Mr Dowden also revealed that over £m has been raised and is being distributed by Comic Relief, Children in Need and the National Emergencies Trust.The Culture Secretary also revealed £m will be handed out to support the smaller local charities helping in the coronavirus fight.Meanwhile, a renewal task force will be set up this week, formed of top people in the creative, tech and sporting sectors.They will advise dferent areas on how to get back up and running, with former Arsenal and England womens footballer Alex Scott among them, helping get sport back safely for clubs, players and fans.The briefing was held today at pm at  Downing Street.Since March , the Government has held these meetings on a daily basis.In the briefings, officials reveal the latest on the coronavirus pandemic.The briefings are broadcast live by the BBC.It can also be watched on the Governments official YouTube page.Also, by following our coronavirus live blog, you will be kept up to date on what is being said at the press conference.Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden chaired the press conference, where he commented on charities, along with ious sectors of sport and media.Alongside him was regular list Professor Stephen Powis, who is the National Director for England in the National Health Service.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pubs could open from july with social distancing minister says
story: Environment Secretary George Eustice stressed again that the nations boozers were still on track to open in weeks, as long as they could space out customers.Mr Eustice told the Commons: Of course we also recognise that until thingsto something closer to normal and they can open normally, hopefully later this summer, then it will not give them all of the trade they previously had.And he added: As the Prime Minister has outlined, we intend that the hospitality sector including pubs would be able to tentatively start gradually opening hopefully during the month of July – subject to the epidemiology supporting such a move.And of course we are already working with the hospitality and pub sector to identy what social distancing measures they might be able to put in place to make that work properly.Mr Eustices comments echoed Dominic Raabs remarks earlier this month, who said pubs and restaurants would be not open until July  at the earliest.He had said: From th July, at the earliest, well look at other sectors and that will include hospitality, but it will also include personal care and people like hairdressers.Obviously the proximity in those two sectors is something where we dont think were ready yet, given where we are with the virus.However, it will likely only include pubs with outdoor spaces or enough room to make sure that groups can keep apart.Scientists say that the virus spreads more in enclosed spaces, and the risk is less outside.Brewers and pubs have suggested that the two metre rule could be reduced to one to open up pubs once again.And the British Beer and Pub Association last week warned that Britain’s , pubs faced pouring as many as  million untouched pints away.BBPA chief executive Emma McClarkin said: “Re-opening in July will be great for those pubs who can meet the social-distancing measures required by then.We stand ready to work with the Government to help pubs re-open in a safe and financially viable way as soon as possible.“Actioning advice from the WHO for example to use one metre for social distancing from July would enable many more pubs to viably re-open and serve their communities again.In mid-May Boris Johnson laid out the first careful steps of easing the coronavirus lockdown as part of a three-phase plan to get back to normal le.In an address to the nation he revealed a detailed roadmap of how to get Britain back on its feet, but still keep the deadly virus under control.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann hope boy found after 32 years
story: Kate and Gerry, who faced the poignant th anniversary of Maddies disappearance a fortnight ago, have been “buoyed up” by the happy news and wish the family who have been reunited with their son “all the best”.McCann spokesman Clarence Mitchell said: “Rare as this very happy event is, wherever a reunion like this happens, of course it gives Kate and Gerry hope that they, too, will one day be similarly reunited with Madeleine”He added: “It also proves that they are right to never give up on their search for their daughter. I know Kate and Gerry will want to wish the family in China all the very best for the future.”Mao Yin was snatched, aged two, from a hotel in the city of Xian in Shaanxi province in October . His dad had stopped to get him some water on the way home from nursery.Over the years his parents searched the country for him and distributed more than , flyers. The overjoyed couple were reunited with their son, now aged , at a police news conference on Monday.Mao, renamed Gu Ningning had been sold to a childless couple for , yuan - £ in todays money.Mao’s mum Li Jingzhi quit her job to search for her “very clever, cute and healthy” son and she appeared on numerous Chinese television shows to appeal for help. She was told the amazing news he had finally been found on May  - Mothers Day in China - saying: “This is the best gt I have ever got.”The investigation into her son’s disappearance is still ongoing. The authorities have not released information about the couple who raised him.Three-year-old Maddie vanished from a holiday apartment in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in May , just nine days before her fourth birthday. She had been left sleeping alone with her younger twin siblings while her parents were dining with pals in a nearby tapas restaurant.Heart doctor Gerry, , and former GP turned medical worker Kate, , from, Rothley, Leics, have never given up hope of finding their daughter alive. She would now be aged .A close friend said: “It shows that dreams can come true and this man being found  years after being abducted is another example that will give Kate and Gerry hope. This is the news they are dreaming of receiving themselves one day. Madeleine is only  so anything is possible.“They believe Madeleine could still be alive and are always buoyed up when they hear stories of kidnapped children being found. It really does give them renewed hope and some joy.”In January  a girl kidnapped in America was found after  years. Newborn baby Kamiyah Mobley was snatched from a Florida hospital by a woman pretending to be a nurse.British police searching for Maddie are working on a final theory that she was kidnapped by a European trafficking gang and sold to a childless couple - her parents and their first team of private investigators initial hunch - and could still be alive and possibly be living in Europe or North Africa.The Operation Grange inquiry to find Maddie, which has cost the taxpayer nearly £ million, is set to receive and extra £, funding from the Home Office to keep it going until the end of March next year.Kate and Gerry wrote in a th anniversary post: The investigation to find Madeleine remains open and continues, even though, in a way dferent to the ideal.We remain grateful for the ongoing efforts and commitment from all those involved in the search to find her and we hope and pray, as always, that our efforts will be fruitful.”

title: weather brits 28c sunshine
story: Sunbathers made the most of their new-found freedom following the easing of lockdown restrictions - but many forgot about social distancing.Thousands of Brits flocked to beaches in Brighton, Bournemouth and Blackpool on what has become the hottest day of the year with temperatures hitting .C at Heathrow Airport this afternoon.But families on the beach in Southend, Essex, appeared to be shunning social distancing advice as they crammed together to get a good spot.Others hit parks in central London and beauty spots across the country after lockdown measures were eased by the government.In the South West, traffic wardens ran out of tickets following an influx of sunseekers flocking to coastal hot-spots.Several routes into beaches in Devon were left clogged with traffic on roads described as exceptionally busy.Cops said several beach car parks had to be closed as people flocked to the seaside to take advantage of the hottest day of the year.The heatwave is set to continue into the bank holiday weekend - with todays pictures causing concern for the RNLI who revealed there are no leguards on any beaches due to the coronavirus outbreak.For the first time ever, they are urging people to not use inflatables in the sea with treacherous surf conditions expected in some areas.All leguard training and recruitment was stopped when the lockdown was announced on March .It means Britains  plus beaches are currently unmanned for the first time since the le-saving patrols were introduced in .The RNLI now fears they will only have enough bodies to patrol  of the UKs beaches during the peak summer season - around  per cent.Last weekend, the Coastguard was called out  times to rescue people and they have now teamed up with the RNLI to launch a joint campaign targeting parents and urging them to take responsibility for their families.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: “For most it’s dry and it’s increasingly sunny during Wednesday afternoon, with temperatures reaching mid-s widely, and up to C in the South East.“It stays warm and bright into the evening, but you can see some thicker cloud approaching Northern Ireland, and outbreaks of rain.”The hot weather is likely to be a test of the new lockdown measures after Boris Johnson announced that Brits can now spend as much time as they like outside – as long as social distancing is observed.Local councils have urged Brits to stick to social distancing and reminded the public that facilities such as outdoor pools and public toilets remained closes.Officers will also be patrolling popular beauty spots and parks to ensure people are abiding by the government’s guidance.Tourist spots have also asked people to stay away with many attractions remaining closed – with the majority beaches not being leguarded.After today’s heatwave, there is a risk of thunderstorms on Thursday in East and South East England as a band of rain pushes eastwards.Temperatures are predicted to cool from C or C before the rain to a fresher C to C on Friday.Met Office meteorologist Greg Dewhurst said: There will be a bit of a grey, misty start for some first thing but that will quickly burn away.The vast majority of the UK will have a dry day with sunny spells,not blue skies all day for some.Mr Dewhurst predicted a windy start to the weekend with sunshine and showers for many with the weather gradually turning drier from the south on Sunday and into bank holiday Monday.While there has been no immediate end to the lockdown, the easing of restrictions meant plenty made the most of the sun – sunbathing and enjoying picnics.The PM said: “You can sit in the sun in your local park, you can drive to other destinations, you can even play sports – but only with members of your own household.”However, he warned: “You must obey the rules on social distancing and to enforce those rules we will increase the fines for the small minority who break them.”  Our journalists strive for title: gyms reopening hong kong social distancing workouts
story: GYMS across the UK are set to look very dferent once the current lockdown measures have eased -photos of reopened gyms in China are anything to go by.Pictures of fitness studios in Hong Kong show treadmills separated by glass partitions, water fountains removed and phone wipe stations.The Government has already warned that gyms wont be able to start reopening until July at the earliest - but this could be later depending on the reduction in numbers of Covid- infections.Studios will also have to pass several tests before opening their doors again to prove they can ensure the safety of gym-goers amid the pandemic.Currently, people are permitted to exercise outside as many times each day as they wish since coronavirus is less likely to spread outdoors.Here, we’ve rounded up what changes could be in place when you finally get to sweat it out in your local gym again...Gyms could follow in the footsteps of ious restaurants and airports across the world and introduce temperature checks.This would involve having a thermometer aimed at your forehead every time you go to the gym to identyyoure sick.If a person has a fever and therefore might be infected with coronavirus, they would then be turned away and urged to seek medical care.Hong Kong gym-goer Virginia Lau revealed on Twitter that she had to give a health declaration on arrival at her gym amid the coronavirus pandemic.This would confirm that youre fit and well and do not have coronavirus.Most gyms and fitness centres have their treadmills and machines packed together pretty tightly, so these could be separated by glass partitions.These iders will help to stop the spread of the virus when two-metre distance, in line with the UK Governments advice, cannot be easily maintained.This has been seen in Hong Kong, China - where gyms are slowly starting to reopen.In a bid to ensure gym-goers are able to maintain the two-metre social distancing rule, do not use signs could be placed on every other machine.Showers and chairs in reception may also be sealed off with signs.While coronavirus isn’t a waterborne virus, gyms may close existing fountains as a precautionary measure.This would minimise any risk, however small, of cross-contamination.Gym-goers will also have to make sure they dont share their reusable bottle with anyone  and clean water bottles between each gym session.Businesses that have been allowed to stay open during lockdown have introduced hand sanitiser stations to help keep customers safe.It could be possible that youll see similar hand sanitiser and phone wipe stations appear at the entrance of gyms as well as next to dferent gym equipment.If you use an alcohol-based hand gel, you need to ensure you use it for  to  seconds, according to the World Health Organisation .Gyms should provide cleaning towels so their clients can wipe down equipment after use.These are likely to be accompanied by sprays, wipes and disinfectant that protect against viruses like Covid-.Like other reopened businesses, you could find social distance signs and markers in your local gym or fitness studio.Gym-goers will have to ensure they keep the two-metre social distancing rule at all times and avoid using equipment directly next to wear someone  is working out.If gyms follow in the footsteps of other establishments that have already reopened doors, youll see your PT and other gym staff wearing a face mask.Staff may also be made to wear gloves when cleaning equipment and checking in members at the front desk.Gyms are likely to increase hygiene measures when they do reopen to help prevent the spread of coronavirus.This would mean all gym equipment and weights being wiped down more often - especially for high use areas such as pin pads, door handles, lockers and equipment.Gym-goers will also have to wipe down the machines theyve been on after use with disinfectant.If gyms follow other establishments, it could mean youll see one-way systems in place when you next visit your fitness studio.This could include doors being used for entrances and exits only.Gyms will likely have to limit the number of people allowed inside at one time.This could mean you may face queuing to get inside.Chatty Dobson, owner of fitness studio FLEX Cha, told The Sun: We will need to reduce class sizes to maintain social distancing, and will be enforcing staggered class check-in time so as not to have a build-up of clients in reception or outside studios before classes.Our bathrooms will be open, but we’re waiting for updates as to whether or not it will be possible for clients to use the showers.As well as the above measures, gyms may also try to focus on outdoor bootcamps, given transmission of the virus is lower outdoors.Chatty added: At the moment everything is very up in the air – we have no indication of how much of our attention should be directed to our reopening.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: modest pittsburgh house inside spaceship beach
story: The modest Pittsburgh home is on for sale for a mere , but it’s only when you step through the door that it comes alive.Photos of the home’s back garden, complete with a circular swimming pool and elaborate greenery reveal the house has a little more to offer than initially thought.More pictures show a fancy spiral staircase, wooden flooring and vintage furnishings.In stark contrast to the vintage touches however, an entire wall in the living area has been painted to resemble space and includes ious planets and what appears to be spaceships.Things take a odd turn when you stumble across a makesht beach, complete with fake sand, seashells and an entire wall painted to look like the sea.But the crowning glory is an entire room designed to look like an actual spaceship out of Star Trek.The room contains a table, presumably for important inter-galactic meetings, and leather-clad chairs.There are also multiple wide-screen TV’s, an image of earth taken from the moon and snazzy black and white led flooring.The listing has gone viral after being unearthed by Twitter user Frazier Approves.“I just discovered the greatest house listing of all time,” he wrote.“It starts out very unassuming and modest. Then, you see the yard and think ‘wow, that’s somewhat surprising’.“Then, you see the interior, and think well that’s not quite what I expected. And before you know it - WHAT THE F*** IS HAPPENING HERE ”The Pittsburgh resident told Bored Panda he across the listing on line.“The front exterior photo is completely unremarkable. It’s very typical of the s Suburban Pittsburgh housing vernacular, particularly in the eastern suburbs, he said.“That’s the kind of home they built for middle-class families in the last days of steel. The first surprise came with the photos of the backyard.“Not only is the yard larger than one would suspect, but swimming pools are exceedingly rare in this region, due to the hilly topography and small window of summer-like temperatures.“Each successive photo reveals another genre-themed room, with an increasing level of commitment.It’s like a miniature amusement park or a home-sized movie studio. It is simply the most amazing home I have ever seen.”Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mysterious abandoned mansion
story: Property millionaire Athanasios Tachmintzis, , lived in the huge house near King’s Langley, Herts, before disappearing more than three years ago.Pictures emerged on Monday showing the faded glory of the abandoned mansion left to rot after the owners seemingly left in a hurry, maybe even in the middle of the night.Neighbours have wondered what caused Mr Tachmintzis to flee the house, leaving furniture, ornaments, designers clothes and even a game of chess on the table.A watch stuck in time was seen on a bedside table, while designer clothes bearing the labels Yves St Laurent, Gucci and Louis Vuitton were stacked up on rails in a bedroom.Empty fish tanks were left lined up in a hallway - while a dishwasher stacked with plates had not been unloaded.A Japanese-theme piano takes pride of place in one of the rooms with the music left out ready to play, while stacks of china were sitting on a living room table next to the sofas.In his huge bathroom, there is a Jacuzzi-style tub with half-used shampoo and conditioner bottles.Amazingly, a potted plant is still alive on a windowsill next to a telescope lined up ready for its owner to look at the night sky.A utility room has a snooker table and outside, four or five cars - including a rusted Bentley - lie in overgrown grass.According to MailOnline, villagers said the dad-of-five lived there for around  years before suddenly vanishing.They said he lived there with his daughters and at least one of his sons.Mr Tachmintzis’ we Sharon, who was born in North Wales, died aged  in .The pair were married for  years and had three sons Alexis, , Nicholas, , and -year-old Paul. They had two daughters Kiristiana, , and Alicia, .It is believed Mr Tachmintzis was so concerned about security he kept Dobermans as guard dogs and employed staff to stand on his gate.One neighbour told MailOnline: “I ride my horse down the road every day and all of a sudden I realised around three years ago that the people there had just disappeared.“I just thought at first that they had gone away somewhere and would then come back – but nobody did. It is most strange.“At first the gates were just shut and then a padlock and chain appeared on them. You could just see the grass getting longer and longer and growing around the cars.“Nobody around here has a clue what happened to them and why they just upped and left. It is a real mystery.“They obviously had loads of money because it is a big house. There were always lots of comings and goings with dferent people going in and out.“They used to have up to three Dobermans. His two daughters would walk them, and sometimes the cleaner would take them out, but they were too big for her to handle and she had to stop.“One day around six-years-ago, this guy in his s came out and said that his dogs had gone missing and he askedwe had seen them, but we hadnt.“The girls were dark haired and very pretty. I think they used to go to a local health club and gym.”Another villager said he heard Mr Tachmintzis made a huge deal involving a luxury property on the exclusive Sandbanks resort in Dorset.They said: “I believe his we had cancer and died several years ago.“He also had a housekeeper, but she left suddenly. It is certainly very odd. Nobody knows what caused them to leave the house, seemingly never to .”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: private schools reopen uk coronavirus
story: Schools across the country will reopened from June , , as the government plans to slowly ease the country out of lockdown.But what does this mean for private schools, will they have to reopen too ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesCurrent guidance government is that schools will begin reopening from June , ,the number of coronavirus infections in the UK continues to decrease.No official guidance has been given on private schools, but it is expected that they will reopen at the same time.This move has sparked controversy, with many insisting it’s not safe to open schools again so soon.Some councils across the country, in places such as Liverpool, are refusing to follow the government guidelines, and will not be telling kids to come back to school.Private schools would find social distancing measures easier to enforce, as they generally have smaller class sizes, it has been suggested.This is because they can use facilities such as sports halls, and theatres to teach classes, making them able to keep social distancing measures in place.Dr Martin Stephen, a former chairman of the Headmasters’ and Headmistresses’ Conference which represents the country’s leading public schools, has said that paid-for schools have spent extravagantly on expanding facilities instead of classrooms.He said: By and large the money they have extravagantly spent over the past  years has not gone into classrooms, it has gone into building sports halls and theatres.For a period of time you can see a situation where sport ceases to exist and that would also apply to music and theatre. Instead, teaching could take place in the sports hall, in the theatre and in the concert hall.All independent schools offer financial help to families, and while it is usually offered when a child enters school, it can be extended to families whose circumstances change.Most private schools have funds available for this situation, and can defer feesthere is a prospect of employment in the future.This is usually up to twelve months, and schools rarely charge interest.Neil Roskilly, chief executive of the Independent Schools Association, said that parents facing financial dficulties should contact their school as soon as possible.Yes, private schools are furloughing staff under the taxpayer funded Covid- scheme.Roskilly also said that many schools were expecting a tough time, as parents hit by the economic impact of coronavirus pull their children out.He said: “There’s this image of private schools being these very well-funded organisations like Eton and Harrow, but the vast majority are nothing like that.They are having to look hard at their teaching staff and think about such things as furloughing.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. full-time, and do not expect schools to implement flexible approaches, such as rota systems.But with some councils discouraging childrensto school, parents have been left confusedtheir kids will be going back.With Year s preparing to sit crucial GCSE exams next year, the Government has included plans for them to get the assistance they need.The Government guidance revealed: We will ask secondary focuses on certain year groups.The purpose of the phased move of reopening is to avoid the spread of the disease at schools.It is also believed that younger schoolchildren are being asked back first title: nurse covid shock pic weight plummeted
story: Mike Schultz, , from San Francisco, who has no underlying conditions, shared his experience on social media to illustrate his virus battle.He posted two images on Instagram: the first was taken about a month before he got sick and the other was snapped at a Boston hospital.Before falling ill, he weighed around  pounds and worked out almost every day, according to BuzzFeed News — but coronavirus ravaged his body and his weight dropped to  lbs.“I wanted to show it can happen to anyone, it doesn’t matteryou’re young or old, have pre-existing conditions or not. It can affect you,” Schultz told BuzzFeed.“I knew what I thought going in [about the coronavirus]. I didn’t think it was as serious as it was until after things started happening.“I thought I was young enough for it not to affect me, and I know a lot of people think that.“I was so weak. This was one of the most frustrating parts. I couldn’t hold my cellphone — it was so heavy. I couldn’t type, because my hands shook so much.”Schultz, who was hospitalized on March , had traveled to Boston to visit his boyfriend, Josh Hebblethwaite, , on March .A week before, they had been to a festival in Miami Beach where at least  people later contracted COVID- and three men died.But Schultz said there were no real restrictions in place, though. No lockdowns.Days after arriving in Boston, he began feeling ill and was soon rushed to hospital with a -degree fever and his lungs full of liquid.He was given oxygen and sedated before being transferred to another hospital where he was intubated for over four weeks.“There was no one  around, and I would be the one to make decisions for him,” Hebblethwaite said. “It was definitely scary.”“About four weeks in, the nurses were nice enough to FaceTime with him.It was pretty much like he was in a coma. It was definitely scary. But I was so happy to see him at that point.”The couple say theyve received a lot of abuse for attending the Florida festival, with some people saying Schultz deserved to get sick.But he said the positive feedback has outweighed the negative comments.After being released from hospital, he enjoyed the two double cheeseburgers, small fries and a strawberry shake he ordered at McDonald’s, although he said his taste was somewhat affected.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: actress barbara de regil abs mexico six pack
story: Barbara de Regil, , has over four million followers on social media, and is as well known for her fitness guides as she is for her film and TV appearances.De Regil, who studied psychology at university, says she achieved her look with a regime of gym exercise and a nutritional diet.She says she avoids sugar, and satisfies her cravings for sweet food with jello, popcorn, or fruit.She also eats a lot of proteins as well as fresh vegetables, and is careful not to eat more than she can burn off.But she doesnt let taking care of her health get in the way of her love of food.“I have a fascination for breakfast, meals, and dinner. For everything, I swear! she said.I love to cook. I’m a fan of food, I enjoy eating healthy. It’s one of my passions.I think thatI wasn’t an actress, I would be a chef.”She also likes to keep herself and her family to a good daily routine, and to make sure she leaves time for her daily workout.“We always try to eat together, she says.And then I go to sleep early because I like to wake up early.”She admits she does occasionally break her diet for her two favourite foods: pizza and ice cream.Her workout films are not always flawless, either.Footage recently showed De Regil fall down a short flight of stairs during a fitness class being live-streamed to , people.In the clip, she picking up two yoga mats before turning to walk down a set of four steps but missing the top one.She falls to the floor onto her side before rolling onto her back and laughing.The video racked up more than , views after she reposted it with the caption: “My live classes are really live.”Dozens of users joked with and expressed concern for the actress.“Is that ankle ok  It hurts just looking,” one wrote.“You need to consume more iron, eat more beans,” said another.

title: wuhan bans sale of bat meat markets coronavirus
story: WUHAN has finally banned the sale of bats and other wild animal meat amid fears coronavirus originated in one of the citys bizarre food markets.The Chinese citys municipal government today announced a comprehensive ban on eating all wild animals and the hunting and trading of wildle.It released a list of strict new rules which will come into immediate effect and will last for at least the next five years.According to the official statement, there will be a ban on the sale and eating of terrestrial wild animals that are both in the wild or bred for the dinner table for dishes like bat soup.Wuhan also announced a complete ban on the hunting of wild animals stating the whole city is now a wildle sanctuary.There will also be prohibitions on breeding aquatic wild animals - like frogs-  for eating and bans on wildle trading in markets and online.This notice shall come into force on the date of promulgation and shall be valid for five years, the the statement read.Wuhan is now the fourth Chinese city to outlaw dangerous practice of selling wild animals for food.The World Health Organisation has previously pointed the finger at the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in the city for the killer outbreak.It claimed many of the first virus victims were stall owners, employees or regular shoppers.The WHO said tests on samples indicated it was the source of the outbreak or had “played a role in the initial amplication”.The Huanan market had a wild animal section where live and slaughtered species were sold for food including snakes, frogs, beavers, porcupines and even baby crocodiles.Close interactions with wild animals have caused numerous disease outbreaks in humans including Ebola, Sars and HIV.Viruses can sp easilyanimals in markets are sick or kept in dirty, cramped conditions, such as in stacked cages.When animals are under duress, viral pathogens can intermingle, swap bits of their genetic code, and possibly mutate in ways that make them more transmissible between species.In the case of respiratory diseases -  like Covid- - the virus can jump to food handlers or shoppers through exposure to an animal’s bodily fluids.Early studies showed the new strain of coronavirus did originate in bats, but scientists have been trying to find which animal then transferred it onto humans.Dferent studies have so-far linked pangolins, stray dogs and snakes to the cause of the deadly outbreak which has so far claimed more than , lives.The search for the source of the virus has become more complex since US-China relations have soured following President Trumps claim it originated in a lab.Mr Trump has repeatedly told the media he has evidence  the virus came from the Wuhan Institute of Virology.But China has responded to these allegations with its own conspiracy theory asserting that American soldiers may have been responsible for the outbreak.News of the ban comes as it is revealed more than , people in Wuhan may have been infected by Covid-.The shock figure comes after an antibody sampling showed a positive rate of five to six per cent in the city.With a population of  million in Wuhan, the findings suggest that up half a million people in the city could have already been struck down.Meanwhile the under-fire city has already screened more than half of its population - including doing half a million tests in just one day this week.Figures released by the Wuhan Health Commission showed a staggering , nucleic acid tests were carried out on Monday.The testing figure was more than the , conducted a day earlier as part of the health authoritys ambitious campaign to test every single one of its residents by th May.Described as a -day battle, the mass testing initiative started on th May, with the central municipal government ordering all  of its districts to come up with their own way to test every resident within its borders.Millions have been queuing inside gated communities, where parks and public squares are being used as assembly points and makesht swabbing stations.Each COVID- test takes about three minutes, while the procedure is free to the public, officials said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hope for uk summer holidays culture secretary
story: BRITS could enjoy a staycation in the UK from July, the Culture Secretary suggested tonight.Oliver Dowden said officials were working on ambitious plans to try and get the UKs tourism sector up and running again within weeks.He was asked this eveningit would be possible for Brits to take a break in the UK this summer, after coronavirus forces hotels and hostels to shut.Foreign Office advice still says nothing but essential travel overseas is allowed.And within the UK Brits can go on a day trip but arent allowed to stay overnight.Hotels form part of the phase three of the lockdown being lted - along with pubs and restaurants - Mr Dowden confirmed tonight.It means they likely wont open again until July at the earliest.Mr Dowden said this evening: I would love to get the tourism sector back as quickly as we possible can.We can only do itits safe to do so.But Mr Dowden said you wont find a bigger champion of the great British break than me this evening.It comes after DWP boss Therese Coffey said yesterday that there may be hope for Brits to go on camping holidays in the summer.Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey told Sky:  Having come from Suffolk down to London, I know there are a lot of campsites that are very keen for people to come.Some of this is being carefully considered, recognising that we have a reduced outdoor transmission risk, that things like camping may well become suitable.She added that it as a decision for later this year, potentially in July as infection rates need to stay down first.English caravan sites are hoping to reopen this summer, with preliminary dates in July - but they are lobbying to open as early as June, in line with plans put forward for sites in neighbouring Wales.Visit Britain boss Patricia Yates says the crisis could actually boost British tourism and urged the nation to take a holiday later in the year.She said: “To get British tourism up and running this summer, and this summer is hugely important is we need that domestic audience.Haven has slashed prices for their caravan hols as they invite guests back on limited package deals, as pools and restaurants will remain closed.Officials at the Department for Transport are looking at the possibility of air bridges so thatthe number of infections stays low - Brits could be allowed to go to other countries where the rate of infection is low too.But No has said this isnt Government policy yet and might not happen.Within weeks the UK will force anyone coming into the country to isolate for  days - title: headteacher tells parents not send kids school
story: Louise McMillan revealed how previously vibrant spaces at St Bede’s Catholic Primary School in Cumbria are now impersonal zones due to new Covid- safety measures.The concerned headteacher pleaded with parents to not allow their poor unfortunate children toas per Government advice on June , as it’s unfair to put them in such abnormal conditions.Her comments received more than , likes on Facebook - with many mums and dads claiming it has inspired them to keep their kids at home.Louise, of Carlisle, Cumbria, wrote: “I know by this point you have stopped reading the comments but I am a headteacher and I’ve been into work this morning splitting my school into impersonal zones.“It doesn’t feel like school, children and staff won’t be able to socialise like they did.“Children in the early years have had just about all the lovely cuddly things stripped from their rooms.“My beautul vibrant rooms are now sterile holding bays for the poor unfortunate children who arrive.“Please don’t send your children, we all want to get back to normal but at the moment this is not normal and not fair to put the children in this environment.“And don’t get me in about putting my staff at risk.”Many mums thanked Louise for her post, with some askingthey could re-post it themselves.One commented: “This is the comment that’s made me decide not to send my year one child back to school in two weeks. I know she would hate it.“Thank you, she’s going back in September.”Another wrote: “It’s so sad to hear how much you care and I trust your professional opinion that confirms that we have made the right decision to keep out children at home until at least September, thank you.  The Government has issued advice on how to make sure classrooms and playgrounds are as secure as possible when they re-open next month - including maximum class sizes of  and keeping desks further apart.And earlier this week, photos emerged of how schools could soon look - with children told to stand in hoops in the playground.One mum said: “It sounds absolutely awful, it’s hard enough for adults in the workplace but for little ones it’s frightening being told to distance from their little friends.A second wrote: “This makes me really sad that you’re having to take away the things that help make primary schools nurturing environments.But some highlighted they need their kids to go back, with one adding: “My child had to go to school, I wish I could make a choice based on this and that evidence that is being discussed, but I can’t.It comes as thousands of schools could defy plans to reopen when the Government wants them to.Justice Secretary Robert Buckland today revealed he was not expecting everyone to be back by then, with at least  councils - and around , schools - expressing concern about the June start date.The plans have sparked a fierce backlash with unions warning teachers not to go, and now councils all over Britain saying they wont sanctions schools who dont reopen.Among those against the plans are Birmingham, Calderdale council in Yorkshire, and Conservative-controlled Solihull, with at least , pupils facing not going back.More councils are expected to join in rejecting the plans today.St Bede’s Catholic Primary School and Cumbria Country Council have been contacted for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: majorca turns back sunseekers coronavirus
story: MAJORCA has begun turning away sunseekers trying to sneak on to the island for holidays by claiming they are working.The news comes after five passengers were forced to fly back to Germany after border cops ruled their reasons for travelling to the tourist hotspot were not valid.Reports said the passengers, who flew from Cologne to the airport Son Sant Joan, were ed to their home country after failing to get past strict police controls.Its been claimed among the five were a retired couple who have a holiday home on sun-soaked Majorca.The anonymous couple told German media: “We were carrying with us the title of the property, the utility bills, and the tests that prove we have not had the disease, but they did not let us pass.”The man added: “At this time of the year we are always in our house in Majorca and it is an outrage that they did not let us in.”No details of the other three passengers were revealed - however they would only have been allowed inthey could prove it was for work reasons.The Spanish authorities also allows foreigners to enter the country   their main residence is in Spain.Those who are allowed in then have to go into lockdown for  days.Reports said the Majorca airport registered the arrival of  passengers and the departure of  travellers this week.Dozens arriving on four international flights to the island were quizzed by the police about their motives to travel to Spain.In March a British woman flying from London to Majorca was also turned away because she was carrying the keys to a friend’s house on the islandEarlier this month, The Balearic Islands government said checks on temperatures for those arriving in the islands would be obligatory.Travellers landing at Majorca airport were later pictured queuing to have their temperatures scanned as Spain began to ease travel restrictions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPlans to reopen schools have been plunged into chaos - as a government minister admits Englandaposs primaries might not all open on June . Englandaposs primaries were told to prepare to bring back year R,  and  pupils back to class, with other primary years ing later in June.  But those plans were hurled into doubt by a mass revolt from unions and councils. Liverpool, Hartlepool, Birmingham, and even Tory-run Solihull and Essex have warned June  might not be possible. Some are looking at later dates, some are still waiting to see what will happen, and some are suggesting s may be part-time - despite the government saying this isnapost an option.Schools are of course already open for vulnerable children and those of key workers. But plans to open them more widely - which involves halving class sizes, hiding away toys, having staggered breaks and making corridors one-way - have ided many in the teaching profession. They need time to prepare, and also want to see the full scientic evidence on whether itaposll be safe. Scientists have also said the government should wait until after a delayed test, track and trace app is up and running. AskedLabour would back councils refusing to open on June , a spokesman for Keir Starmer said: “Ultimately councils will want to do what is in the best interests of children and families in their respective area. The infection rate ies from area to area so it’s not surprising some councils have particular concerns.” The government has insisted the June  date was at the earliest and schools wouldnapost be reopenedit was unsafe. Today one minister, Robert Buckland, admitted they may not open unormly across England. In Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland they will remain shut to the wider population. So what have dissenting councils in England said  Hereaposs what we know so far. These are all the areas weaposve found so far expressing doubt about the governmentaposs plans. But the situation is changing fast so itaposs inevitable some are probably left out. If you know one which should be added to this list, please e-mail dan.bloom@mirror. Barking and Dagenham Council leader Darren Rowell: “I cannot support any school reopeningit puts at risk the safety of our teachers, staff and young people.. Simply forcing schools to reopen without taking steps to reduce the risk of the virus spread is unacceptable… We can’t put people at risk by rushing back to normality before it’s safe.” Birmingham We only support Birmingham schools opening to more pupils when it is safe to do so. We are committed to having due regard to the guidance that has been issued by the government. However, we recognise that for some schools, opening to more pupils safely may not be possible on  June.  Bradford Bradford Council has no intention of directing schools to open on June  or to force parents to send their children back and we are committed to working in partnership with school leaders, families and trade unions so that they can make sure their schools are safe environments for our children whenever they choose to open. Parents will not be finedthey choose not to send their children back to school at this time. Brighton and Hove We have strongly advised our schools that they should only reopen to more children when their risk assessments indicate it is safe to do so. It is likely that wider re-opening will happen at dferent times for dferent schools and for dferent numbers of children, given each school’s particular circumstances. Bristol Mayor Marvin Rees: You cannot just make a blanket statement on Bristol. What we’ve said is we will back our schools to make the decision they have to make. Bury While high levels of Covid- infection in the north west remain, and guidance around practical arrangements for social distancing within educational environments, testing and tracing, and supply of PPE is unclear, the borough will not be re-opening schools on June .  Calderdale Adam Wilkinson, lead member for children and young people: We are advising schools in Calderdale not to extend opening on  June. We are keen to get more pupils back to school, but safety is of paramount importance  we have been advised by public health professionals that governments key tests have not been met. Durham Schools in County Durham are being advised that they should only start a phased reopening when they feel it is safe to do so.  Essex Whilst all schools are working hard to respond to the guidance provided by the Department for Education, depending on each inidual school context, some primary, infant and junior schools may not be able to offer full-time provision for the relevant year groups, and any new arrangements may not be introduced exactly from the st June. Gateshead We have absolute confidence that each school will determine the risk, and will make the right decision for their schools, pupils, staff and parents. The council will fully support any school that after careful consideration of all these factors, determines that they cannot comply with government instruction. Hartlepool We have agreed [schools] will not reopen on Monday  June. Whilst we recognise the importance of schools reopening, we want to be absolutely clear that we will be taking a measured and cautious approach to this. We continue to work with schools to put in place appropriate measures to help keep children and staff safe when a phased reopening is possible.”

story: NewsBritish Airways should hand back the British flag over coronavirus job cuts - Labour MPA Labour MP lashed out at the UK flag carrier, which plans to slash jobs as it deals with the Covid- crisisShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsBA is among airlines which have grounded planes during the pandemic " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAirlines were accused of exploiting the coronavirus crisis to slash jobs and workersapos pay today. British Airline Pilotsapos Association general secretary Brian Strutton told MPs carriers were “egging the pudding too much to take advantage of the crisis”. British Airways came under heavy attack during a two-hour session of the cross-party Commons Transport Select Committee. There were also hints passengers could boycott the carrierpotential fliers were unhappy with BAaposs actions. BA is among several airlines planning redundancies as the aviation industry battles the Covid- crisis. Planes across the globe were effectively grounded as lockdown and travel restrictions were imposed. Ryanair plans , jobs losses and to cut staff pay by up to a fth.  Virgin Atlantic plans to cut more than , jobs and shut its operations at Gatwick Airport. BA has announced plans to axe , posts – more than a quarter of its workforce – and senior BA cabin crew face a % pay cut under a proposed new contract. IAG, which owns British Airways, claims it does not expect demand for air travel to recover before , while Gatwick Airport has said it could take up to four years. But Mr Strutton told MPs: I believe that airlines are exaggerating the problem. The predictions that some of the airline leaders are saying, of up to a five or six-year recovery, is not in line with industry standard predictions.  Last week, the International Air Transport Association – which is usually the touchstone for these things – issued its new projections and said that by the end of  we would be back to  levels. Weaposre in a trough at the moment, we will be coming out of it over the next two-and-a-half years, and I think that airlines are egging the pudding too much to take advantage of the crisis to make changes and downsize their workforce unnecessarily. Unite union assistant general secretary Diana Holland told the committee she was extremely concerned about the industryaposs future. She said: If there isnapost revenue coming in to the industry itaposs not just the airlines , itaposs the airports, itaposs everything down the line and of course all the people that work there. We are extremely worried about the future, and thataposs why we need to come together now to look at what plan we have to restart, to rebuild confidence and to make sure that jobs, pay terms and conditions – while there maybe temporary changes as we reach that point – arenapost decimated for the future.” Ms Holland admitted there may be temporary changes to jobs, pay, terms and conditions, but stressed they must not be decimated for the future. Conservative MP Chris Loder said Government support to BA was being used “as a buffer in order to allow them to progress considerable numbers of redundancies”. Labouraposs Sam Tarry said: “We see a parent company that has assets in the region of £billion, we see a company that has thousands of staff on furlough.” He accused the firm of using the crisis to “restructure the company”. Mr Tarry urged the Government to tell BA to “hand back the British flag because they donapost seem able to be supporting British jobs, able to represent our country globally”.  Committee chairman Huw Merriman accused BA of an “opportunist an underhand approach to their workforce”. Aviation Minister Kelly Tolhurst told MPs Iaposve spoken with representatives at BA and obviously Iaposve expressed my disappointment. She added: I think the British public will make their own views on the actions of certain airlines. Ms Tolhurst admitted “any announcement around job losses or consultation round redundancies or terms and conditions is deeply worrying”. She insisted the threat of job losses keeps me awake at night. I am under no illusions to the impact and the concern that those iniduals will be feeling at that time, and what the consequences could be for some of them,” she said.

Thereaposs then a .pm bullet-point update with the dayaposs headlines. Donapost miss a thing - sign up for the Mirror Politics newsletter by visiting www.mirror email. Areas which were already among the worst off suffered most, the Institute for Employment Studies said. Torsten Bell, chief executive of living standards think-tank the Resolution Foundation said it showed “Britain’s jobs crisis has now arrived”. Calling for more support for young people he urged the Government to “repair our social security safety net” to protect those facing financial ruin. But Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Jonathan Reynolds warned: “Unfortunately, these claimants will now discover the UK has one of the weakest out-of-work safety nets in the developed world.” It came as the number of people who have died after testing positive for the virus rose by  to , and figures suggested around , elderly care home residents have died. Gordon Brown lashed out at an apparent lack of leadership, with Boris Johnson “hiding” from the public recently. Mr Johnson, seen ing from a run yesterday, has led the daily Downing Street briefing just twice since going back to work on April . He has given one Commons statement on the pandemic since it began. While Mr Brown said he would “take into account” the fact Mr Johnson had been ill, he insisted he needed to tell Parliament his strategy for protecting lives and jobs. Mr Brown said: “He has got to get a grip on the testing and he has got to get a grip on what is going to happen to the economy as it moves forward.” The Government is also facing growing pressure from councils and teaching unions to reconsider plans to open primary schools in England. Experts have predicted the unemployment rate could eventually hit %, up from .%. And Mr Sunak told the House of Lords Treasury Committee via video­link “the jury is out” on what the economy will look like after the crisis.  “I certainly won’t be able to protect every job and every business,” he said. “We’re seeing [it] in the data and no doubt there will be more hardship to come. We are likely to face a severe recession the likes of which we have not seen.” The Institute for Employment Studies said many of the areas worst hit by the rise in unemployment were in the North West of England. In Blackpool, % are now “claimant unemployed”, up from % in March. Elsewhere, one in  residents are claimant unemployed in Middlesbrough, South Tyneside, Birmingham, Wolverhampton and Thanet, Kent. In another sign of the bleak employment landscape, there was a record fall in job vacancies, down , to , in the three months to April. There are also fears over the effect that increased unemployment will have on the nation’s health.  The Institute for Fiscal Studies has said a % rise could lead to a further one million people developing chronic health conditions. Unemployment was already on the rise, climbing by ,, to . mil­­lion in the three months to March. The number of paid employees plunged by , at the start of April to . million but this excluded eight million currently furloughed. Calling for more support for young people Mr Bell also warned against a sharp clf-edge end to furlough.

title: hope brits holiday parks prepare
story: NewsHaven, Butlins, camping and caravan sites make changes as Brits plan staycationsSome of the UKs leading holiday parks are putting plans in place to reopen this summer with new rules that will allow families to maintain social distancingShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsBrits may get summer holidays after all " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s top holiday parks and resorts are preparing for a summer boom as tourism bosses urge lockdown-weary Brits to enjoy a staycation and help boost the ailing sector. Haven, Center Parcs and Butlin’s are drawing up plans to adapt their sites to cater for families’ “pent-up demand to get away” while sticking to vital social distancing rules.They are hoping the Government clears holiday parks and resorts to reopen in July – under what would be Phase Three of Boris Johnson ’s plan to ease us out of lockdown and reboot the hospitality sector.It comes after Visit Britain said the domestic market, worth £billion, has already lost £billion as a result of Covid- measures. The group wants families to make  the “year of domestic tourism”. Acting chief executive Patricia Yates told the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee: “To get British tourism up and running this summer – and the summer is hugely important – you’re going to need that domestic audience.” She added there was “a real job to be done” to convince people it is acceptable to “enjoy a holiday and that it’s safe to do so”. But figures from coolcamping. com, covering  locations, show summer bookings for campsites have soared % in the past week. The website said: “There’s clearly a pent-up demand to get away. The mooted date of July  is ideal timing for summer and could save many businesses who have had no income.” Rethinks on how resorts and parks operate will help reassure people mulling a staycation. Haven says planned measures range from Perspex screens at reception and info desks to check-ins from home. On-site grocery stores will have the same social distancing rules as supermarkets, while restaurants will just do takeaways and deliveries. Hand- washing stations will be dotted around all  parks and there will be reduced numbers on sites – with communal areas like swimming pools will staying closed.Haven said: “Our prices have been adjusted to recognise the revised experience. We’ve made signicant changes, which we anticipate will allow us to open as soon as Government deems it safe. We’ll comply with coronavirus restrictions.”Center Parcs, which has six UK sites, is also hoping to reopen in July and said holidaymakers could expect to see “some changes”. A spokesman said: “We are reviewing the whole experience to ensure we can open with appropriate social distancing as well as any other measures required to keep our staff and guests safe. “We know we can adapt and provide reassurance to guests and staff, and will only reopen when the time is right. When we do, we are confident we will provide a great guest experience for families.” Butlin’s said fewer people would be allowed in entertainment venues and it would increase the number of shows. There will be more sittings for meals as well as extra events so that kids do not miss out on activities. The firm said: “We are awaiting guidance as to when we can reopen. “In the meantime, we’re using all of the skills and creativity of our team to plan a break that keeps everyone safe.” The Camping and Caravanning Club, which represents , sites, said caravanners will park six metres apart and tents will also be pitched with large gaps between them. Its plans include asking campers and caravan owners to bring their own portable loos so toilets can stay closed. Bosses offered to do a trial reopening after losing £million of bookings due to Covid-. Camping and Caravanning Club director general Sabina Voysey said: “We’re well-placed to offer socially-distanced holidays and eager to work on trial schemes for how campsites may reopen with all necessary measures. “We urge the Government to provide greater clarity on how the sector can safely open and operate.” The plans to get staycations firmly on the radar emerged as airlines slammed a bid by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps to boost uptake of foreign holidays as unworkable. Mr Shapps raised hopes of travel to top hotspots by striking up no-quarantine deals, or “air bridges”, with countries where infection rates are low. Britain’s biggest tour operator, Tui, said it hopes to kick-start the season from June . The firm got a boost after Portugal and Greece revealed they were willing to relax quarantine restrictions for Britsit was a two-way system. Algarve Tourism Board head Joao Fernandes said: “If British holidaymakers are allowed to fly to countries with low infection rates via ‘air bridges’, without having the need for quarantine, the Algarve will be the place to be.” But airlines said the scheme was at odds with the Government’s two- week quarantine rules for anyone coming into the UK, effective from next month, and a Foreign Office ban on non-essential travel abroad. The PM’s official spokesman said air bridges were “an option under consideration but not agreed policy”.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The Duchess of Cambridge shared a throwback snap of her getting her hands dirty in the garden to celebrate the first anniversary her taking part in the Cha Flower Show. Kateaposs Back to Nature garden, designed to highlight the benefits of nature to mental and physical well-being, was a big hit at last yearaposs show. It also got a big thumbs up from Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis, who had a chance to explore their mumaposs creation before it opened to the public, with the eldest Cambridge kid giving it  out of . This yearaposs Cha Flower Show has been cancelled due to coronavirus, but is running as a virtual event, which Kate promoted by sharing a throwback snap on social media.It shows her getting involved with the garden build, wearing gloves as she balances on two rocks being handed a plant ready to be in the ground. Sheaposs casually dressed in muddy jeans, trainers and a green shirt, with her hair tied back in a messy bun. The caption reads: One year on from The Duchess of Cambridgeaposs Back to Nature Garden, the Cha Flower Show is going digital!Visit  @The_RHS  to join the virtual #ChaFlowerShow  for practical gardening advice from world-leading designers and experts all from the comfort of your own home. The Duchess’s Back to Nature garden in  aimed to highlight the physical and mental health benefits of the natural world and inspire children, families, and communities to enjoy the great outdoors. Yesterday, the Queen shared a message of support of the new virtual event, praising organisers for making sure it can continue during these uncertain times. She said: “On the occasion of the Opening of the Virtual Cha Flower Show , I send my best wishes to all those associated with the Royal Horticultural Society.  “My family and I have always enjoyed visiting the Show, and I know that your Members and Supporters will be disappointed that they are unable to attend in person this year. “As Patron of the Royal Horticultural Society, I was pleased to hear that you will be providing gardening advice and virtual sessions on your website, from Monday th to Saturday rd May. “I am sure that my grandmother, Queen Mary, who first attended the Cha Flower Show in , would be delighted that many people today have an enthusiasm for horticulture, and that gardening remains a popular past time in the United Kingdom.  “As you adapt to the present circumstances, I hope you find this unique event enjoyable and interesting.” Kate designed her  garden alongside landscape architects Andree Davies and Adam White and the Royal Horticultural Society . The garden, which Kate hoped would inspire families to get outside and enjoy nature, featured a tree house, swing seat, waterfall, rustic den and a campfire as well as tree stumps, stepping stones and a hollow log for children to play on. Kate remembered the late Diana, Princess of Wales by including forget-me-nots, her favourite flowers. Among the blooms and foliage were blue periwinkle flowers, geraniums, astrantias, wild strawberry plants, ferns and rhubarb. Trees planted in the garden included a weeping beech tree, which is an ideal base for building a den under branches.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKFC has been slammed for reportedly serving fried chicken with the animalaposs feathers still attached. The horried customer shared the images appearing to show feathers poking through the outside of the coating of her KFC. The incident happened when the Blackpool mum used Uber Eats to order a delivery from a branch in Blackpool. She snapped images of the hot wing, saying that her young son said that the feathers looked like small legs dangling from the piece of chicken.On closer inspection, she said she found three large feathers which had seemingly been coated and fried along with the rest of the food, Lancs Live reports.The anonymous woman said: “I have received an apology, refund and also been told that in no circumstances should I have been sent that food. “KFC should notgiving this to a customer, surely it’s not good food hygiene to leave feathers attachedthat’s what they are.” She later revealed that the refund had come from Uber Eats, not KFC, and that she had only received around half of her money back - £.. “I won’t ever eat KFC again,” she said. “Because I ordered from Uber Eats I only got a partial refund just for the meal even though the lot was wasted. “When I went to KFC the manager just came over to my car in the car park and he couldn’t give me a refund as I had ordered from Uber.”

he was pleased Her Majesty had approved a knighthood for Captain Tom Moore who raised millions for NHS charities.The Queens Honours list has been delayed :KEY EVENTUK coronavirus death toll reaches , with  more fatalitiesSports and culture Secretary Oliver Dowden is hosting today#xs daily Downing Street coronavirus briefing.He said ,  people in the UK across all settings including hospitals and care homes have died with Covid-.Thatis an increase of  fatalities since yesterday.Read more here.Oliver Dowden :World records highest number of new cases of coronavirus infection in a single day There were , new cases of new coronavirus infection recorded worldwide in the last  hours - the most in a single day yet, the World Health Organisationsaid today.Its leader has expressed concern for poor countries even as wealthier nations begin to emerge from lockdown. #xCWe still have a long way to go in this pandemic,#xD WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told a news conference on Wednesday. #xCWe are very concerned about rising cases in low and middle income countries.#xDResidents wait in a queue to be tested while in Alexandra, South Africa :McDonalds accused of hating the North as it reopens  southern drive-thrusMcDonald#xs has released the locations of the  restaurants now open again for deliveries, drive-thru or both - but not one is in the North of England.The fast food restaurant chain#xs choice of locations to reopen amid the coronavirus lockdown has led to some salty accusations.Fans desperate for a burger and fries are accusing McDonald#xs of playing into a North-South ide.Read more here. :British Airways should hand back the British flag over coronavirus job cutsAirlines have been accused of exploiting the coronavirus crisis to slash jobs and workers#x pay today.British Airline Pilots#x Association general secretary Brian Strutton told MPs carriers were #xCegging the pudding too much to take advantage of the crisis#xD.BA came under heavy attack one city could have been caused by VE Day partiesA sudden spike in Covid- cases in Bradford, West Yorkshire could have been caused by VE Day celebrations, a medical expert said today.Prof John Wright, head of the Bradford Institute for Health Research at Bradford Royal Infirmary , said there were  new cases six days after VE Day on May .Up until that point, the number of cases at the hospital had been reducing, with only three reported on Monday May .But three days later, on Thursday May , the number of cases shot up to a staggering  - a figure Prof Wright suspects has come from VE parties that ended in #xCfist fights or embraces#xD.Writing in a diary for the BBC, the professor, who is a doctor and epidemiologist with expertise in the cholera, HIV and Ebola epidemics in sub-Saharan Africa, said: #xCIt#xs just one figure, and in normal times we might discount it as random iation.#xCHowever these are times of alertness, and every flicker of the Covid dashboard needle triggers nervous anticipation of a possible spike. So these cases would have been incubating since the week before - and possibly since the communal gatherings on VE Day, six days earlier.#xDPolice were called to several VE Day street parties around the UK amid complaints about people not following social distancing guidelines.Read more here.Royal Air Force Red Arrows perform a VE Day flyover :Police paying London congestion charge when other key workers exempt branded slap in the faceA decision to make police officers pay the re-imposed London congestion charge when other key workers are exempt has been described as a #xCslap in the face#xD.Ken Marsh, chairman of the politan Police Federation, said officers should not be #xCpenalised#xD for travelling to their shts.The #xA. daily levy for people driving into central London was suspended on March  when the lockdown was announced.But it was reintroduced on Monday as part of a billion-pound government bailout to secure emergency funding for Transport for Londonso underground and bus services could be kept running until September.Next month the fee will rise to #xA and the hours of operation will be extended. Those who do attempt to access the site will be asked to leave. Thank you.#xDThe festival, which runs every August, has been cancelled due to the pandemic. Kendrick Lamar, Paul McCartney and Taylor Swt were among this year#xs planned headline acts.Glastonbury  is cancelled due to the Covid- pandemic :Why Boris Johnsons pledge to have test and trace by June  isnt what it seemsBoris Johnson has grabbed headlines by promising to have a #xCtest and trace#xD system up and running by June .The Prime Minister boasted he has #xCgreat confidence#xD the system will be ready - ensuring new outbreaks of Covid- are swtly contained.He said by June  there will be , contact tracers, all working to hunt down anyone who#xs been exposed to the deadly disease.But Mr Johnson#xs cleverly-worded statement doesn#xt actually promise a full test, track and trace programme by June .Here#xs why - and what he said instead.Boris Johnson More OnCoronavirus
